thread.title: Tesco's Dunnhumby suitors said to have abandoned auction
thread.title_full: Tesco's Dunnhumby suitors said to have abandoned auction

title: Tesco's Dunnhumby suitors said to have abandoned auction
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Tue, Sep 8, 2015, 14:34 BST - UK Markets close in 1 hr 56 mins Tesco's Dunnhumby suitors said to have abandoned auction By Michele Maatouk | Sharecast – 27 minutes ago 1,361.00 +23.0000 
LONDON (ShareCast) - (ShareCast News) - Private equity firms have reportedly abandoned their offers for Tesco (Xetra: 852647 - news ) 's data arm, Dunnhumby, after the retailer struck a deal with the unit that raised concerns over financing. According to Sky News , buyout groups including Apax Partners, CVC Capital Partners, Clayton Dubilier & Rice and TPG (Taiwan OTC: 6521.TWO - news ) are losing interest or no longer in the frame for the acquisition, which is now valued at under £1bn - less than half original estimates. 
Sky (LSE: BSY.L - news ) cited people familiar with the matter as saying that General Atlantic Partners, which had been involved in a joint bid with marketing services giant WPP (LSE: WPP.L - news ) , has decided not to pursue a deal. 
Tesco recently struck a five-year agreement with the unit which manages its Clubcard loyalty scheme. However, that deal expires in 2020 meaning that a new owner will have to secure another deal with the company which currently accounts for more than half of Dunnhumby's revenues. 
A number of private equity bidders withdrew on the basis of that deal, having struggled to secure acceptable borrowing terms from banks. 
The news come a day after Tesco announced the sale of its South Korean unit, Homeplus , to a consortium led by MBK Partners for £4.24bn. 
Tesco said the deal, which is expected to complete in the fourth quarter, will allow it to significantly reduce its £4.23bn debt pile. 
Reports on Monday also said that Tesco was exploring a potential sale of its central and eastern Europe business .
